citation.article-title: Propionispora vibrioides, nov. gen., nov. sp., a new gram-negative, spore-forming anaerobe that ferments sugar alcohols.

p.s: Description of Propionispora vibrioides sp. nov.
Propionispora vibrioides (vi-brio-i'des. M.L. masc. n. vibrio that which vibrates, a generic name, Gr. n. eidos shape; M.L. adj. vibrioides vibrio-shaped)
Cell shape as for the genus, 0.6×2.2–6μm in size, cells only slightly swollen during sporulation in comparison to Sporomusa species.
Growth and fermentation substrates are polyols, such as erythritol, xylitol, mannitol and sorbitol as well as fructose.
Glycerol is fermented in the presence of acetate and pyruvate, but allows only weak growth.
Glucose, xylose, pyruvate, lactate, C4-dicarboxylic acids, alanine and alcohols are not fermented.
Fermentation products are propionate, acetate, CO2 and small amounts of H2.
Addition of biotin allows some growth in chemically defined media, but much better growth and substrate conversion is obtained in the presence of yeast extract.
The type strain is FKBS1, deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen (DSMZ) as DSM 13305.
